nodes.bodyText: maybe use already defined constant if such exists or extract constant/variable
static import Duration will be more readable
I'm not sure if this is a "failure".  I feel like this is more like "authentication was redirected to..."... BTW just a nit
This inner class retains a live reference to the config object, which is mutable.  Instead, the values should be read out of the config and assigned to fields.
same
Is there a pure java OIDC server we can use instead?  I'd prefer to avoid Docker if there is Java one we can use.

There are a few alternatives such as: https://www.gluu.org/ and https://www.keycloak.org/ and a bunch of solutions built on top of Spring Framework Security lib such as: https://github.com/cloudfoundry/uaa. I've chosen ORY Hydra because it's lightweight, have well built docker image and extracts login & consent flow to an external app which might be handy in the future https://www.ory.sh/hydra/docs/login-consent-flow/.
We already have pem files for localhost that are used by TestWebUI. cert/localhost.pem
I believe these field names are defined in a specification.  We should note the spec, or at least add a comment saying "don't change these field names"
There is guava method for this Strings.isNullOrEmpty... there might be something in the JVM that does this
same comment about config objects
Static import
I would use toString for this, and maybe replace the constructor with a valueOf method.
When doing chaining, don't put a newline for the first call.
This will compile the regular expression for each call.  Instead just do something like header.substring("Bearer ".length())
Why both?
I've removed unnecessary AutoCloseable.
These methods look to be part of the public interface of this class, so they should be public

Jetty is an implementation detail of Airlift HTTP server. Anything we need from Jetty should be added as an abstraction in Airlift. Adding a specific Jetty version here could conflict when we upgrade in Airlift.

nodes.bodyText: UrlJwkProvider is not good. It uses URLConnection which is ancient and has various problems, and doesn't allow configuration of things like TrustStore, proxy, etc., except by setting global system properties (which we clearly do not want users doing). We should write our own using Airlift HTTP client so that users can fully configure it as they do with other components.
I'm going to use @dain's JWK implementation after #5419 has been merged.

I added auth0 library to presto in our internal version to get JWKS working with Presto. I ended up changing auth0 code to support proxy so that I can access remote JWKS endpoint (not directly accessible from presto production environment). Looks like Dain's work will eliminate this need.
No need to add a new dependency for this. We already use OkHttp in test code, so you can use HttpUrl.
execute() returns a Response which needs to be used in try-with-resources
There is no guarantee the chosen port is unused.
Doing this as a global static seems like the wrong way to go. We don't do this anywhere else. Instead, we should start the container and ask for its port.

It's a different kind of problem. Here we're exposing the host's port to the selenium-driver container and it has to be done through this static method. Additionally, this method have to be called before the start of the containers so it's sort of "the chicken or the egg" problem as the Presto server needs to know the Hydra's port before the start.
We should not hard code and assume the container is running on 127.0.0.1
Exception class names normally end in Exception

nodes.bodyText: We should leave this choice to the JVM configuration. Instead, just do new SecureRandom() like we do elsewhere.

Since this is just for tests, you could do
UUID.randomUUID().toString().replace(" ", "");

Is OAuth2 the right name for this authenticator?  I believe this assumes assumes that tokens are in JWT format, which I believe is part of the OIDC specification.  If true, should we rename this OidcAuthenticator (and the package to oidc)?
OIDC is a layer which sits on top of OAuth2 and since this code implements only the OAuth2 spec I think the name is appropriate.
use oauth2Binder... same for everything below this
consider adding a OAuth2SupportModule like is did in the JWK PR where I addedJwtAuthenticatorSupportModule.
Nothing in this class logs, and I don't think this log message adds value.  If someone were interested in this they can get the information from the http log
This isn't needed.  The only caller is the FormWebUiAuthenticationFilter and that class already directly calls abortWith
There is a method location method that sets the LOCATION header.  This is similar to the seeOther method we already use in the form authenticator
All of the methods here down can be static
It is not clear why we would need to check anything other than "cookie" for this PR
Well, I thought is just a few lines of code but it makes the api more versatile. I can delete it, if you like.
I would follow the style of the other Authenticators and add a needAuthentication method that encapsulates this logic
You can do checkArgument(code.isPresent() != error.isPresent(), "Either code or error should be present"); and combine these
This will cause the OAuth library to use the JVM HTTP client which we have never used in Presto.  This raises a bunch of questions like how do I configure the trust stores for this client?
ScribeJava supports multiple http clients so I can any from the list: https://github.com/scribejava/scribejava#async-and-other-http-clients
Additional we can add our own implementation of the HttpClient interface but I would prefer not doing this in this PR.
I assume we are still dropping this.

I'm pretty sure we don't need a cache.  We just need a way to prove that the "state" is one generated by this cluster.  We can replace the state with an encrypted value, so we know the cluster created the value.  Then is it is transported/stored in the client.
BTW, the value of the cache only contains the State and an authorization url which is not used after the original redirection, so we don't need the Started object here.
The state stored in the cache is going to be needed by clients such as JDBC/CLI so implementation with an encrypted value won't last long.

I find this code quite difficult to understand. I think the biggest issue is the abstractions as they chop up the logical flow across a bunch of classes.  I think the code would be much easier to understand if this class and the Challenge hierarchy were inlined.
Specifically:

startChallenge can be inlined into OAuth2Authenticator.  This method is really only one line of code.
finishChallenge can be inlined into OAuth2Resource.  Once the Challenge code is inlined also, that class could be come much simpler and I will be able to see the full authorization flow much more concisely.

I'm not sure if I agree. In my opinion having the logic of a stateful challenge encapsulated in a single class improves the readability. However, I'll try to improve it even further but without inlining since storing challenges in a cache is going to be needed (see: #5355 (comment)).
@NotNull
I would squash that with the commit that relies on it.
separate commit?

This should be error_uri
Do the formatting using the logger, so that we only construct it if the log level is enabled

From my quick search it looks like it's uncommon to wrap error strings in quotes and I would prefer to be coherent.
Static import
Add @ConfigDescription for all of these new properties
Add @ConfigDescription

I don't think @NotNull is needed for these, since they can't ever be set to null. The purpose of the validation annotations is for the framework to verify the user code used the class correctly, but this would be a bug in the bean class itself.
I think I suggested that :(
Change this to return directly
Put this on previous line so we don't have unnecessary indentation
Should this be addressed? Seems like it could be a bug
The difference is only 1 second and I believe it's due to selenium's rounding of the expiration time.

We used to do this and it made tests unreliable. Can we do this a different way?
It's my second attempt to solve this problem. The first one was based on choosing a random port from a wide ranger of ports and you didn't like it either so I'm open to suggestions.
Let's make this a method on TestingPrestoServer since we do this in several places now
Change this class to implement AutoCloseable, then this catch block is not needed
Changing it to AutoCloseable makes harder to use it in our case which involves: Closeables.closeAll(server, testingHydraService).
Closeables supports AutoCloseable now
That's right, changed.
This code is duplicated with TestOAuth2WebUiAuthenticationFilter. Would it make sense to add a method on TestingHydraService to do this?

This code is also duplicated in TestOAuth2WebUiAuthenticationFilter. Can we move it somewhere common?
While duplication is not always a problem, since this is a main() method, it's not tested, so having it use tested code is better.
It's not so straight forward as in the previous case and there are quite a few differences between those two places and I would prefer to leave it as it is.
